author: GEORGE ALFANO
title: REIGN: Rally nets win in home opener
text:
By GEORGE ALFANO / CONTRIBUTING WRITER
Published: Oct. 23, 2015 Updated: 11:13 p.m. ONTARIO – Local fans of the Ontario Reign couldn’t be faulted if they wondered whether the team might have left its magic in Manchester, N.H.
The Manchester Monarchs won the 2015 Calder Cup, which is awarded to the American Hockey League champions.
The AHL is the highest-ranking North American hockey league after the NHL.
The Manchester franchise moved to Ontario, which places it within driving range of the Kings at Staples Center.
After showing a fairly weak offense for the first half Friday, Ontario burst out with three goals in 56 seconds, overcoming a three-goal deficit and earning a 5-3 victory Friday night over the Bakersfield Condors in the first AHL game played at Citizens’ Business Bank Arena.
“The players on the team are very good at evaluating their own play,” Reign coach Mike Stothers said. “You can either rant or you can tell them they still have plenty of time. We were standing around too much in the first period, but then we got our feet moving.”
Michael Mersch scored his third goal of the season with 5:32 remaining in the second period when he tapped his own rebound by the glove side of Ben Scrivens, the former Kings’ goalkeeper who played for the Edmonton Oilers most of the 2014-2015 season.
“Michael Mersch is too good for this league,” Stothers said. “He is going to be playing in the National Hockey League soon and I hope it is for the Kings.”
Kris Newberry scored six seconds later, tapping Sean Backman’s missed shot in the net on the glove side.
Valentin Zykov tied the score at 15:24 of the second period, coming up with the third goal.
Kevin Gravel snapped the tie when he blasted a shot from inside the blue line below the crossbar with 2:50 remaining in the second period.
Zykov gave the Reign what proved to be a needed insurance goal at 6:57 of the third period.
“We wanted to keep playing our game and generate some energy and positive things,” said Zykov, a 20-year-old forward from St. Petersburg, Russia who played in the Quebec Major Junior Hockey League.
